thread.title: FX’s dark, funny ‘Fargo’ is better than ever, don’t you know
thread.title_full: FX’s dark, funny ‘Fargo’ is better than ever, don’t you know | Boston Herald

author: Mark Perigard
title: FX’s dark, funny ‘Fargo’ is better than ever, don’t you know
text:
Now this is how you do a black comedy.
FX’s “Fargo” anthology series returns for a new season with a darn good story, don’t you know , as the ever-so polite natives might say.
Its latest “true crime” story is one that was alluded to last season — and so this show dials back in time to 1979 to tell the saga of the Gerhardt crime family and all those, good and bad, who fall under its shadow.
When patriarch Otto (Michael Hogan, “Battlestar Galactica”) suffers a stroke, it sets off a power struggle between his wife Floyd (Jean Smart, “24”) and their three sons, Dodd (Jeffrey Donovan, “Burn Notice”), Bear (Angus Sampson) and Rye (Kieran Culkin, “Scott Pilgrim vs. the World”).
Rye has ambitions and resents his older brothers for making him work collections.
“You’re the comic in a piece of bubble gum,” Dodd tells him.
The family couldn’t suffer a worse time to be divided, what with a Kansas crime syndicate, fronted locally by Joe Bulo (Brad Garrett, “Everybody Loves Raymond”) and enforcer Mike Milligan (Bokeem Woodbine, “Southland”) closing in on their operation and looking to buy them out — or bury them — whichever is easier.
“I think history has proven people of the Germanic persuasion don’t surrender easy, but you can kill ’em,” Joe says.
Rye’s attempt to fix a court case results an epic tableau of terror that is both hilarious and horrifying. This is how it’s done, “Scream Queens.” As for Rye, he discovers what goes around sometimes runs you over.
And what do Peggy (Kirsten Dunst. “Spider-Man”) and Ed (Jesse Plemons, “Breaking Bad”) Blumquist have to do with any of this? Why, they’re just the nicest couple. She’s a beautician and he’s a butcher’s assistant and he’s hoping to buy the shop and he wants kids, but on “Fargo” what you want and what you get might as well be the difference between the moon and a moon pie.
“You’re kind of a bad girl, aren’t you?” Peggy’s boss says admiringly in the Oct. 19 episode. She doesn’t have a clue.
State trooper Lou Solverson (Patrick Wilson, “The Conjuring”) is stuck investigating the rising body count, and he’s helped by his father-in-law, Sheriff Hank Larsson (Ted Danson, now on “CSI: Cyber”), though, to be fair, Lou’s wife Betty (Cristin Milioti, “How I Met Your Mother”) turns out be better than anyone at finding evidence. (You might remember Lou and daughter Molly from the first season, when they were played by Keith Carradine and Allison Tolman. Here, Molly is but a child.)
Every performer here brings his or her A-game, and the little nods to the day — such as the chatter about a seminar that will help “actualize” the attendees or the salesman who believes that the electric typewriter represents an unparalleled technological revolution — are both striking and sad. Writer Noah Hawley (who also serves as executive producer along with the Coen brothers) has concocted a wicked brew of characters, crime and a touch of crazy. The show is shot like no other prime-time show and features split-screen work and, befitting “Fargo,” a frozen backdrop that seems as forlorn as most of its characters.
“Well, this is a deal,” Hank comments while surveying a murder scene. Like everyone here, he’s underplaying it. Not me. “Fargo” is terrific.
